Wouldn't it be better to create a system that uses nutrients, and photosynthetic microbes to make the structures of wood? Thinking a gmo microtree that can make the structure of wood and be grown in the desired shape. Or use photosynthetic cells that create wood precursers as a byproduct which can then be altered chemically to make the desired structures. Added benefit of both is in using sunlight to reduce atmospheric co2. And in the second case if enough sunlight still travels through the microbes perhaps this could be used over solar panels to generate some electricity, maintain warmer temperatures for the microbes and reduce the temperature of the solar panels.

Now what I find more interesting is the paper published in Nature this year that makes super solid wood out...wood.


Essentially they dissolve some of the lignin in a bath of NaOH, and then compress the wood...making it 10 times as dense, and comparable in strength to some forms of steel! That means we can build large structures out of wood frames. Like the timber skyscraper already in Sweden, but sleeker.

While of course advances in material science and science in general is noble goal, we do not need this to save the forests. Most of the wood we use these days are from tree farms. The trees we want to save, is being cut down to clear land for farms and towns. Fake wood won't help what this video indicate it will.

If you want to use wood and wood products responsibly, go for FSC certified wood/products. SFI is ok, but FSC is the best widely adopted standard there is. It’s all about sustainable management of wood resources that preserves the ecological conditions of harvested areas. Little to no clear cutting, pollution and environmental damage controls, etc. Wood composites have their uses, but we don’t need to go faking wood when we can just manage what we have and use it sustainably.

I’m in favor of cutting down tree wood use by utilizing bamboo in framing. Entire structures within the walls that make our buildings, structures of their own that are covered out of sight with insulation, drywall and paint. Bamboo typically grows about 2” a day as an average among breeds, is soil regenerative, stronger than wood both compressive and tensile rated, moisture resistant, not typically engaged by pests, and thanks to modern breeding has some which can grow in as low as almost -20c. And, we can turn it’s fibers into planks with similar properties as it’s raw rods/stalks yet looks like a contemporary, bright Maple, but is surprisingly easily dyed, like normal planks, to be magenta if you want magenta, much less a rich ebony we pretty much have standardized.

Just gotta send some code creators over to do some learning from Asia. Hell, I just watched a video a few months ago about Chinese construction workers making the siding of a skyscraper out of bamboo rods, fastened with a bamboo rope because twisted even moderately well it did sturdier fastening than the toughest, most ideally driven nails.

Imagine how much more sustainable construction would be if the space that grew one house worth of trees in 25 years grew 25 houses worth of bamboo in one month?

Compared to old, stagnant forests, properly managed forests and tree farms that are thinned regularly or logged and regrown on a cycle mean stronger trees that grow faster and trap more carbon, clearer and more useful lumber for practical human uses like construction, healthier trees and a greater diversity of plant life that better resist parasites and disease, and improved environments with more variability for fauna to live and find food.

Maybe the issue isn't trying to replicate wood. Maybe the issue is we need to get over our assumption that a material has to look like wood to function as a building material. As long as the material performs at or outperforms wood, it should be fine.


Sometimes, it's our expectations that are unrealistic.

If you read what the early explorers wrote about the forrests when they were exploring the West, you will find that the average number of trees was about 40 per acre. There is a lot more now due to our meddling with nature by putting out the natural fires.

Using wood could actually be a more ecological option. Trees take years, decades or even centuries to grow and they fix a lot of cabon in their wood meanwhile. Using wood for structres keeps that carbon fixed and the demand "protects" forests to be used as anything else but growing.

Concrete requires a to put a lot of carbon in the atmosphere and it's not reusable. Same with polymers . And, if wood is not used, then other options become more viable for the forests, like transforming them into grazing for cattle.

As a journeyman builder/contractor who's worked with all sorts of natural and composite materials over the past couple of decades (and stays up to date with new products tested by the NRCC), I'm not sure that introducing more plastics to our landfills and failing recycling programs that just dump materials in developing countries, is the best way to deal with deforestation. I see what my industry uses, wastes, and dumps on a daily basis. It's incredible. A better, honest effort in sustainable development and enforcing responsible forest management/farming will get us farther ahead than exacerbating one problem in a vain attempt to solve another.
